data.message:
The idea is that you can have different classes for top, bottom, right and left arrows, that all share the same parts that make an arrow at all.

This is what I did in the second example, starting at 7:56
http://youtu.be/tRjYbpfBhco?t=7m56s

If I'm building a reusable CSS style for arrows, I'll use a base class with multiple classes for multiple directions. If it's a one-time thing, I'll use one class.

Note that the dropdown example uses one class only. The example starts at 9:43
http://youtu.be/tRjYbpfBhco?t=9m43s
but I have a question, could we change this drop-down:after with a css low level compatiable
because you know that pseudo-elements not supported in IE7 and it's partial supported in IE8

If you mean support older IE versions than 8, then maybe. There is a library https://code.google.com/p/ie7-js/ which has a demo for just that here http://ie7-js.googlecode.com/svn/test/after.html
In reality, if you add this library late in the development and you have very complex design, it can have bad side effects.

Frankly, if you worry about IE7 support, then just use actual SPAN elements or so. I wouldn't use :before and :after. Your selector could then change to something like ".drop-down > .arrow". The project I worked on recently was for a bank. We did worry about IE7 support, IE7.js fiddled with other complex things we built, so, we just added empty elements.
do you mean you didn't show the arrows in ie7 and display an empty element instead ?
I tried the IE7.js but I found it not good at all in the complex code so I leave it.

I meant I have an empty element at the end of the drop-down (for all browsers), and target it with CSS instead of targeting :after. Like:
http://jsbin.com/evecar/1/edit
